so here's the thing about these star
fires a couple things you got to look
out for okay
the original star fire the first ones
came out in 1960 and in 60 and 61 they
had different pickups they were called
dearmond Dino Sonic's like you would
find out a 50s Gretsch 6120 and those
are really good pickups but they're very
noisy and they're a totally different
vibe than these mini humbuckers that
they started using in 62 these minis
lasted from 62 up to about 66 and then
they went to a full-size Umberger which
is still pretty cool but the magic ones
are these 62 63 64 65 star fires start
fires came in many configurations one
one through seven the higher the number
the more pimped out it was this is a
Starfire 3 Bigsby and I've and it's got
the original aluminum Bigsby bridge on
it now one more thing I want to tell you
and then I'm gonna shut up but these
when you buy one of these if you buy one
of these you can get them for less than
2 grand still you got to find one that's
got a good break angle behind the bridge
see that sometimes these old star fires
you'll find it there's no brake angle at
all behind the bridge and the string
just basically goes straight back and
then you got problems because every time
you try to play out but you know
something with any velocity the string
pops out of the saddle it's not good and
then at that point the only way to fix
it is to reset the neck and that's very
expensive so if you're shopping for a
Starfire make sure you find a mini
humbucker one with good break angle
behind the bridge it's very important
see it break angle behind the bridge is
basically everything if you don't got
any break angle the whole guitar just
feels wrong it's very important on any
guitar really
